Expectation1: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation1: The mentor fit the session into the last hour before boarding a long flight.
Expectation2: Enforcing the law and maintaining public order
Situation2: A noise complaint is reported due to a late-night party disturbing neighbors
Story: I glanced at my watch, nerves prickling. My mentor had squeezed in this session just before catching a red-eye flight, and I knew how precious her time was. I wanted to make the most of every minute, to show her I respected her effort and commitment. We were deep in conversation, her advice finally helping me see a way forward in my career, when my phone buzzed—dispatch. A noise complaint, late-night party, neighbors upset. As a police officer, I was expected to respond immediately, to keep the peace and enforce the law. But if I left now, I’d waste my mentor’s rare availability and possibly damage our relationship. If I stayed, I’d be neglecting my duty, letting down the community and my colleagues. My heart pounded as I weighed the demands, feeling the pressure of two worlds pulling me in opposite directions, each expecting my full attention, each unwilling to wait.
